abstract: Study in journal Proceedings of the Royal Society B uses radiocarbons from nuclear weapons tests, which have accumulated in shells of hawksbill sea turtles, to estimate turtles' age, growth rates and reproductive maturity; data, which is being used to pinpoint why some populations of world's seven marine turtle species have failed to bounce back, points to late maturity and poor food sources.

headline.print_headline: Nuclear Clues to a Turtle’s Decline
headline.main: Old Nuclear Fallout Proves Useful for Sea Turtle Clues

keywords.value: Proceedings of the Royal Society B (Journal)
keywords.name: organizations

snippet: Researchers are relying on radiocarbon from bomb tests decades ago to learn more about endangered hawksbill turtles in the Hawaiian Islands.
lead_paragraph: Researchers are relying on radiocarbon from bomb tests decades ago to learn more about endangered hawksbill turtles in the Hawaiian Islands.
